item.title: Android emulator access to local server
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: How can you connect your app on an Android emulator to a development server running on the localhost of your computer? The problem # Since Android emulators create their own virtual network, they cannot access devices on your local network.

item.title: Transfer many large files from Android
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Trying to get a large number of files from your Android phone, but Android File Transfer freezing up? Here’s what I learned trying to pull ~170 Gb from my Pixel phone.

item.title: Share code between Android and Jvm in Kotlin multiplatform
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: While Android supports most Java language features, it doesn’t support every API that Java provides. On the other hand, Kotlin multiplatform only allows sharing code across all targets (commonMain), not a subset of targets (commonJvm).

item.title: Migrating away from JCenter
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: This week JFrog - out of nowhere - announced to completely remove their Maven repository. Since they’ll pull it offline already by May 2021 (!!!) it’s time to urgently migrate away.

item.title: Test library releases using an in project Maven repository
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Short, powerful post on how to test the release version of libraries directly within a project without having to deploy them to Maven first. As a bonus, there will also be an open-source example showcasing all of this in action.

item.title: Android library development - Dependencies
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Ever had a build failure while integrating an SDK? Wonder how you can avoid your SDK customers having dependency conflicts? How many transitive dependencies should your SDK have?

item.title: Android library development - Modularization
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: With modularization being all the hype, should you also modularize an SDK? Are fat aar files really needed? And how do you prevent internal APIs from being exposed on your public interface?

item.title: Android library development - Getting started
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Having switched to Android SDK development over the past year, I’ve run into quite a few interesting and unexpected challenges. So how does library development differ from app development?

item.title: Feature flags - A successful architecture
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Now that we know how feature flags can help us release faster, it’s time to dive into the actual implementation details. How can we easily define feature flags?

item.title: Feature Flags - How to use
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Empowered with what feature flags are and why they are useful, let’s see how we can actually integrate them into an app. And how can we roll them out to our users?

item.title: Feature Flags - Why you should care
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: A key ingredient to speed up modern software development is feature flags. But what is a feature flag precisely? Why should you care about them? How do you integrate them into your codebase?

item.title: Philips Hue adaptive icon
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Your icon is one of the most important assets in your app. With a bit of luck, users might even put it on their main launcher screen!

item.title: Modularization - A successful architecture
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)

item.title: How dangerous permissions sneak into apps
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: This is a post-mortem where the very dangerous permission, READ_PHONE_STATE, unintentionally sneaked into our app. Here’s how this could happen, how we debugged and finally how we solved it.

item.title: The curious case of haunting fragments
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Do Fragment transactions and back navigation have no more secrets for you? Well then you should try to solve the mystery in this post, where a Fragment (literally) came to haunt us…

item.title: The 100% code coverage problem
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: While you may be tempted to strive for 100% code coverage, that would be a horrible idea. Besides some code being hard to test, the concept of coverage is actually fundamentally limited.

item.title: The career opportunity called Kotlin
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: This isn’t another post about the benefits of using Kotlin. Hell, I’m not even going to cover any of its language features. Nor will I try to convince you to make the switch.

item.title: Embracing Java 8 language features
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: For years Android developers have been limited to Java 6 features. While RetroLambda or the experimental Jack toolchain would help, proper support from Google was notably missing.

item.title: Implementation vs API dependency
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Upgrading to Android studio 3.0 territory will make building multi-module projects a lot faster, but it also means a breaking Gradle plugin API change unfortunately.

item.title: My Google #io17 takeaways
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Being my 2nd year at Google IO, I decided to do things differently: Besides taking notes during sessions, I also created a personal todo list. This contains all new (and even old) technologies I got triggered to look into.

item.title: Android Makers FR recap
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: After organizing Droidcon Paris for several year, the organizers decided to move on and experiment with a new format. This didn’t just result in a well organized conference, but also in a fresh new vibe whilst still feeling familiar.

item.title: Why your app should crash
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Too many times I’ve seen developers trying to avoid crashes at all cost. But are unhandled exceptions really that bad? And are null checks really the answer?

item.title: Write awesome unit tests
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: If you can code, you can also write unit tests. Writing awesome tests on the other hand is a different story. Don’t fool yourself: Unit testing code is production code that you will need to maintain, refactor and build upon for years to come.

item.title: Using Mockito 2.x on Android
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: The Mockito team is on fire lately! Not only did they add support to mock final classes and methods, but now they allow running Mockito directly onto an actual Android device.

item.title: Extending Mockito
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Due to its clean simple api, Mockito has become world’s most popular Java mocking framework. After having covered all of its basics, it’s time to spice things up and start extending Mockito.

item.title: The hidden cost of code coverage
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: Code coverage is an awesome way to motivate you and your team to write more tests. But did you know that simply enabling it slows down your build significantly?

item.title: Why you should care about copyright
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: As die hard Android developers, copyright notices are usually not on top of our priority list. Yet large corporations always insist to add a copyright header.

item.title: Testing made sweet with a Mockito
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: At Droidcon Berlin 2016 I had a great time talking about testing using the Mockito framework. While the talk wasn’t recorded unfortunately, the great folks at Voice Republic recorded an audio version which you can listen to as a podcast or together with the slides.

item.title: Droidcon Berlin recap

item.title: Efficiently reducing your method count
item.author: info@jeroenmols.com (Jeroen Mols)
item.description: As green field projects are a rare breed, chances are that you’ve inherited a legacy code base. If you’re as lucky as me, that code base has over 65k methods causing the build times to be boringly slow.

item.title: Droidcon Italy recap

item.title: A private Maven repository for Android in 30 min
